comment_text.mn127:2.1: For Pañcakaṅga and his role as chamberlain, see note on MN 59:1.3.
comment_text.mn127:4.6: At MN 43:29.5, Mahākoṭṭhita asks Sāriputta a similar question about different meditative liberations.
comment_text.mn127:5.1: “Without fail” renders apaṇṇaka, for which see note on MN 60:4.3. It’s an unusual response. As apaṇṇaka means a “set without a fifth”, Anuruddha might be punning on Pañcakaṅga’s name, which means, “a set of five items”.
comment_text.mn127:7.1: “Limitless” is appamāṇa. This set of four meditations is known in later traditions as either the “divine meditations” (brahmavihārā) or the “immeasurables” (appamaññā).
comment_text.mn127:8.1: “Expansive” renders mahaggata, literally “grown great”. This features as a state of mind that is developed in satipaṭṭhāna (MN 10:34.10), and which is known with psychic powers (MN 6:16.10). It also appears just above next to “limitless” in the description of the divine meditations, a detail that perhaps prompted Pañcakaṅga’s question.
comment_text.mn127:8.2: This meditation practice is unique to this passage. It might be compared with the practice of emptiness at MN 121:4.1, which likewise moves from a perception of one’s limited surroundings towards something more universal. The meaning of “pervading” (pharitvā) might be understood in the same sense as it is found in the divine meditations, where I have translated it as “spread”. The sutta below, however, treats it as the spreading of light. In this interpretation, the “expansive” practice is a method of spreading love (etc.) by gradually expanding the perception of the field of love. The final extent is the land bordered by ocean, beyond which the mind become “limitless like the great ocean” (MN 72:20.2). In other words, the “expansive” liberation leads to the “limitless” liberation.
comment_text.mn127:9.1: “Rebirth in a future life” renders bhavūpapatti. This section explains how the meditation one develops can shape one’s rebirth.
comment_text.mn127:9.4: The gods of limited radiance are mentioned at MN 41:18–42.22, where they are reborn due to a limited practice of the second absorption.
comment_text.mn127:9.7: Normally the suttas maintain a clear distinction between the “corrupted” (saṅkiliṭṭha) mind that is purified before attaining the radiance of absorption. This passage, however, suggests that things might not always be so clear-cut.
comment_text.mn127:12.6: This example shows that “craving for rebirth” need not be conscious.
comment_text.mn127:13.1: We meet Sabhiya Kaccāna also at SN 44.1, where he is questioned by Vacchagotta. His verses are at Thag 4.3. The conversion of a wanderer named Sabhiya is recorded in Snp 3.6; this might be the same person.
comment_text.mn127:13.5: For tadaṅgena in the sense “in that respect”, see AN 9.33:1.3.
comment_text.mn127:17.4: The phrase cited by Sabhiya here, “so I have heard” (evaṁ me sutaṁ), is the standard opening for Buddhist suttas. This passage illustrates that this tag was used in order to indicate that the speaker was not present at the events, but “heard” about them. This is in contrast with the phrase “I heard and learned this in the presence” (sammukhā sutaṁ, sammukhā paṭiggahitaṁ), which is used when reporting a teaching heard directly from the Buddha, eg. SN 55.52:5.1, SN 22.90:9.1, MN 47:10.7, etc.
comment_text.mn127:17.8: Sabhiya is bluntly asking about Anuruddha’s personal meditation attainments. It is a minor offence to declare these to lay people, but they may be discussed among monastics (Bu Pc 8). In this case, Anuruddha is speaking to a monastic while at least one lay person can overhear, a situation not addressed in the Vinaya.

root_text.mn127:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
root_text.mn127:2.1: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn127:2.2: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mama vacanena āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandāhi:
root_text.mn127:2.3: ‘pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandatī’ti;
root_text.mn127:2.5: ‘adhivāsetu kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa svātanāya attacatuttho bhattaṁ;
root_text.mn127:2.6: yena ca kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pagevataraṁ āgaccheyya;
root_text.mn127:2.7: pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati bahukicco bahukaraṇīyo rājakaraṇīyenā’”ti.
root_text.mn127:2.8: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho so puriso pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa paṭissutvā yenāyasmā anuruddho tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so puriso āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn127:2.9: “pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati āyasmato anuruddhassa pāde sirasā vandati, evañca vadeti:
root_text.mn127:2.10: ‘adhivāsetu kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa svātanāya attacatuttho bhattaṁ;
root_text.mn127:2.11: yena ca kira, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho pagevataraṁ āgaccheyya;
root_text.mn127:2.12: pañcakaṅgo, bhante, thapati bahukicco bahukaraṇīyo rājakaraṇīyenā’”ti.
root_text.mn127:3.1: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho tassā rattiyā accayena pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya yena pañcakaṅgassa thapatissa nivesanaṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā paññatte āsane nisīdi.
root_text.mn127:3.2: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ paṇītena khādanīyena bhojanīyena sahatthā santappesi sampavāresi.
root_text.mn127:3.3: Atha kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ bhuttāviṁ onītapattapāṇiṁ aññataraṁ nīcaṁ āsanaṁ gahetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn127:3.4: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho pañcakaṅgo thapati āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn127:4.1: “Idha maṁ, bhante, therā bhikkhū upasaṅkamitvā evamāhaṁsu:
root_text.mn127:4.5: Yā cāyaṁ, bhante, appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti—
root_text.mn127:4.6: ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca, udāhu ekatthā byañjanameva nānan”ti?
root_text.mn127:5.1: “Tena hi, gahapati, taṁyevettha paṭibhātu, apaṇṇakante ito bhavissatī”ti.
root_text.mn127:5.3: ‘yā cāyaṁ appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti ime dhammā ekatthā byañjanameva nānan’”ti.
root_text.mn127:6.1: “Yā cāyaṁ, gahapati, appamāṇā cetovimutti yā ca mahaggatā cetovimutti ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
root_text.mn127:6.2: Tadamināpetaṁ, gahapati, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
root_text.mn127:7.2: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu mettāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ mettāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:7.5: upekkhāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ tathā tatiyaṁ tathā catutthaṁ; iti uddhamadho tiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ upekkhāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyābajjhena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.2: Idha, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.4: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.6: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ gāmakkhettaṁ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.8: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.10: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ mahārajjaṁ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.12: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.14: Idha pana, gahapati, bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ mahaggatanti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:8.16: Iminā kho etaṁ, gahapati, pariyāyena veditabbaṁ yathā ime dhammā nānatthā ceva nānābyañjanā ca.
root_text.mn127:9.3: Idha, gahapati, ekacco ‘parittābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:9.4: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā parittābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:9.5: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘appamāṇābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:9.6: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā appamāṇābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:9.7: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘saṅkiliṭṭhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:9.8: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā saṅkiliṭṭhābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:9.9: Idha pana, gahapati, ekacco ‘parisuddhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:9.10: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā parisuddhābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:10.1: Hoti kho so, gahapati, samayo, yā tā devatā ekajjhaṁ sannipatanti, tāsaṁ ekajjhaṁ sannipatitānaṁ vaṇṇanānattañhi kho paññāyati no ca ābhānānattaṁ.
root_text.mn127:10.2: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, puriso sambahulāni telappadīpāni ekaṁ gharaṁ paveseyya.
root_text.mn127:10.3: Tesaṁ ekaṁ gharaṁ pavesitānaṁ accinānattañhi kho paññāyetha, no ca ābhānānattaṁ;
root_text.mn127:10.4: evameva kho, gahapati, hoti kho so samayo, yā tā devatā ekajjhaṁ sannipatanti tāsaṁ ekajjhaṁ sannipatitānaṁ vaṇṇanānattañhi kho paññāyati, no ca ābhānānattaṁ.
root_text.mn127:11.1: Hoti kho so, gahapati, samayo, yā tā devatā tato vipakkamanti, tāsaṁ tato vipakkamantīnaṁ vaṇṇanānattañceva paññāyati ābhānānattañca.
root_text.mn127:11.2: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, puriso tāni sambahulāni telappadīpāni tamhā gharā nīhareyya.
root_text.mn127:11.3: Tesaṁ tato nīhatānaṁ accinānattañceva paññāyetha ābhānānattañca;
root_text.mn127:11.4: evameva kho, gahapati, hoti kho so samayo, yā tā devatā tato vipakkamanti, tāsaṁ tato vipakkamantīnaṁ vaṇṇanānattañceva paññāyati ābhānānattañca.
root_text.mn127:12.1: Na kho, gahapati, tāsaṁ devatānaṁ evaṁ hoti:
root_text.mn127:12.2: ‘idaṁ amhākaṁ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā devatā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā devatā abhiramanti.
root_text.mn127:12.3: Seyyathāpi, gahapati, makkhikānaṁ kājena vā piṭakena vā harīyamānānaṁ na evaṁ hoti:
root_text.mn127:12.4: ‘idaṁ amhākaṁ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā makkhikā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā makkhikā abhiramanti;
root_text.mn127:12.5: evameva kho, gahapati, tāsaṁ devatānaṁ na evaṁ hoti:
root_text.mn127:12.6: ‘idaṁ amhākaṁ niccanti vā dhuvanti vā sassatanti vā’, api ca yattha yattheva tā devatā abhinivisanti tattha tattheva tā devatā abhiramantī”ti.
root_text.mn127:13.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn127:13.3: Atthi ca me ettha uttariṁ paṭipucchitabbaṁ.
root_text.mn127:13.4: Yā tā, bhante, devatā ābhā sabbā tā parittābhā udāhu santettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti?
root_text.mn127:13.5: “Tadaṅgena kho, āvuso kaccāna, santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti.
root_text.mn127:14.1: “Ko nu kho, bhante anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo yena tāsaṁ devatānaṁ ekaṁ devanikāyaṁ upapannānaṁ santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.2: “Tena hāvuso kaccāna, taṁyevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.
root_text.mn127:14.4: yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.5: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.6: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.9: yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā rukkhamūlāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ gāmakkhettaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.10: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.11: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ gāmakkhettaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.13: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ gāmakkhettaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.14: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.15: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.17: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā gāmakkhettāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ mahārajjaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.18: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.19: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ mahārajjaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.21: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā ekaṁ mahārajjaṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.22: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.23: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.25: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, āvuso kaccāna, yvāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā dve vā tīṇi vā mahārajjāni ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati, yo cāyaṁ bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.26: imāsaṁ ubhinnaṁ cittabhāvanānaṁ katamā cittabhāvanā mahaggatatarā”ti?
root_text.mn127:14.27: “Yvāyaṁ, bhante, bhikkhu yāvatā samuddapariyantaṁ pathaviṁ ‘mahaggatan’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati—
root_text.mn127:14.29: “Ayaṁ kho, āvuso kaccāna, hetu ayaṁ paccayo, yena tāsaṁ devatānaṁ ekaṁ devanikāyaṁ upapannānaṁ santettha ekaccā devatā parittābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā appamāṇābhā”ti.
root_text.mn127:15.2: Atthi ca me ettha uttariṁ paṭipucchitabbaṁ.
root_text.mn127:15.3: Yāvatā, bhante, devatā ābhā sabbā tā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā udāhu santettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti?
root_text.mn127:15.4: “Tadaṅgena kho, āvuso kaccāna, santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti.
root_text.mn127:16.1: “Ko nu kho, bhante, anuruddha, hetu ko paccayo, yena tāsaṁ devatānaṁ ekaṁ devanikāyaṁ upapannānaṁ santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti?
root_text.mn127:16.3: Upamāyapidhekacce viññū purisā bhāsitassa atthaṁ ājānanti.
root_text.mn127:16.4: Seyyathāpi, āvuso kaccāna, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi aparisuddhaṁ vaṭṭipi aparisuddhā.
root_text.mn127:16.5: So telassapi aparisuddhattā vaṭṭiyāpi aparisuddhattā andhandhaṁ viya jhāyati;
root_text.mn127:16.6: evameva kho, āvuso kaccāna, idhekacco bhikkhu ‘saṅkiliṭṭhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati,
root_text.mn127:16.7: tassa kāyaduṭṭhullampi na suppaṭippassaddhaṁ hoti, thinamiddhampi na susamūhataṁ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccampi na suppaṭivinītaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn127:16.8: So kāyaduṭṭhullassapi na suppaṭippassaddhattā thinamiddhassapi na susamūhatattā uddhaccakukkuccassapi na suppaṭivinītattā andhandhaṁ viya jhāyati.
root_text.mn127:16.9: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā saṅkiliṭṭhābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:16.10: Seyyathāpi, āvuso kaccāna, telappadīpassa jhāyato telampi parisuddhaṁ vaṭṭipi parisuddhā.
root_text.mn127:16.11: So telassapi parisuddhattā vaṭṭiyāpi parisuddhattā na andhandhaṁ viya jhāyati;
root_text.mn127:16.12: evameva kho, āvuso kaccāna, idhekacco bhikkhu ‘parisuddhābhā’ti pharitvā adhimuccitvā viharati.
root_text.mn127:16.13: Tassa kāyaduṭṭhullampi suppaṭippassaddhaṁ hoti, thinamiddhampi susamūhataṁ hoti, uddhaccakukkuccampi suppaṭivinītaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn127:16.14: So kāyaduṭṭhullassapi suppaṭippassaddhattā thinamiddhassapi susamūhatattā uddhaccakukkuccassapi suppaṭivinītattā na andhandhaṁ viya jhāyati.
root_text.mn127:16.15: So kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā parisuddhābhānaṁ devānaṁ sahabyataṁ upapajjati.
root_text.mn127:16.16: Ayaṁ kho, āvuso kaccāna, hetu ayaṁ paccayo yena tāsaṁ devatānaṁ ekaṁ devanikāyaṁ upapannānaṁ santettha ekaccā devatā saṅkiliṭṭhābhā, santi panettha ekaccā devatā parisuddhābhā”ti.
root_text.mn127:17.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn127:17.4: ‘evaṁ me sutan’ti vā ‘evaṁ arahati bhavitun’ti vā;
root_text.mn127:17.5: atha ca pana, bhante, āyasmā anuruddho ‘evampi tā devatā, itipi tā devatā’tveva bhāsati.
root_text.mn127:17.7: ‘addhā āyasmatā anuruddhena tāhi devatāhi saddhiṁ sannivutthapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā’”ti.
root_text.mn127:17.8: “Addhā kho ayaṁ, āvuso kaccāna, āsajja upanīya vācā bhāsitā,
root_text.mn127:17.10: ‘dīgharattaṁ kho me, āvuso kaccāna, tāhi devatāhi saddhiṁ sannivutthapubbañceva sallapitapubbañca sākacchā ca samāpajjitapubbā’”ti.
root_text.mn127:18.1: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā sabhiyo kaccāno pañcakaṅgaṁ thapatiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn127:18.3: yaṁ tvañceva taṁ kaṅkhādhammaṁ pahāsi, mayañcimaṁ dhammapariyāyaṁ alatthamhā savanāyā”ti.

translation_text.mn127:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.
translation_text.mn127:2.1: And then the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga addressed a man,
translation_text.mn127:2.2: “Please, worthy man, go to Venerable Anuruddha, and in my name bow with your head to his feet. Say to him,
translation_text.mn127:2.3: ‘Sir, the chamberlain Pañcakaṅga bows with his head to your feet.’
translation_text.mn127:2.4: And then ask him whether he
translation_text.mn127:2.5: might please accept tomorrow’s meal from Pañcakaṅga together with the mendicant Saṅgha.
translation_text.mn127:2.6: And ask whether he might please come earlier than usual,
translation_text.mn127:2.7: for Pañcakaṅga has many duties, and much work to do for the king.”
translation_text.mn127:2.8: “Yes, sir,” that man replied. He did as Pañcakaṅga asked, and
translation_text.mn127:3.1: Then when the night had passed, Anuruddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to Pañcakaṅga’s home, where he sat on the seat spread out.
translation_text.mn127:3.2: Then Pañcakaṅga served and satisfied Anuruddha with his own hands with delicious fresh and cooked foods.
translation_text.mn127:3.3: When Anuruddha had eaten and washed his hands and bowl, Pañcakaṅga took a low seat, sat to one side,
translation_text.mn127:4.1: “Sir, some senior mendicants have come to me and said,
translation_text.mn127:4.2: ‘Householder, develop the limitless release of heart.’
translation_text.mn127:4.4: ‘Householder, develop the expansive release of heart.’
translation_text.mn127:4.5: Now, the limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart:
translation_text.mn127:4.6: do these things differ in both meaning and phrasing? Or do they mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing?”
translation_text.mn127:5.1: “Well then, householder, let me know what you think about this. Afterwards you’ll get it without fail.”
translation_text.mn127:5.3: The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart mean the same thing, and differ only in the phrasing.”
translation_text.mn127:6.1: “The limitless release of the heart and the expansive release of the heart differ in both meaning and phrasing.
translation_text.mn127:6.2: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
translation_text.mn127:7.1: And what is the limitless release of the heart?
translation_text.mn127:7.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn127:7.3: They meditate spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.mn127:7.4: They meditate spreading a heart full of rejoicing …
translation_text.mn127:7.5: They meditate spreading a heart full of equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.mn127:7.6: This is called the limitless release of the heart.
translation_text.mn127:8.1: And what is the expansive release of the heart?
translation_text.mn127:8.2: It’s when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading the extent of a single tree root as expansive.
translation_text.mn127:8.3: This is called the expansive release of the heart.
translation_text.mn127:8.4: Also, a mendicant meditates focused on pervading the extent of two or three tree roots …
translation_text.mn127:8.15: This too is called the expansive release of the heart.
translation_text.mn127:8.16: This is a way to understand how these things differ in both meaning and phrasing.
translation_text.mn127:9.1: Householder, there are these four kinds of rebirth in a future life.
translation_text.mn127:9.3: Take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘limited radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:9.4: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of limited radiance.
translation_text.mn127:9.5: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘limitless radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:9.6: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of limitless radiance.
translation_text.mn127:9.7: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:9.8: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of corrupted radiance.
translation_text.mn127:9.9: Next, take someone who meditates focused on pervading ‘pure radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:9.10: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.
translation_text.mn127:9.11: These are the four kinds of rebirth in a future life.
translation_text.mn127:10.1: There comes a time, householder, when the deities gather together as one. When they do so, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.
translation_text.mn127:10.2: It’s like when a person brings several oil lamps into one house.
translation_text.mn127:10.3: You can detect a difference in their flames, but not in their radiance.
translation_text.mn127:10.4: In the same way, when the deities gather together as one, a difference in their color is evident, but not in their radiance.
translation_text.mn127:11.1: There comes a time when those deities go their separate ways. When they do so, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.
translation_text.mn127:11.2: It’s like when a person takes those several oil lamps out of that house.
translation_text.mn127:11.3: You can detect a difference both in their flames and also in their radiance.
translation_text.mn127:11.4: In the same way, when the deities go their separate ways, a difference both in their color and also in their radiance is evident.
translation_text.mn127:12.1: It’s not that those deities think,
translation_text.mn127:12.2: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.
translation_text.mn127:12.3: It’s like when flies are being carried along on a carrying-pole or basket. It’s not that they think,
translation_text.mn127:12.4: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those flies cling, that’s where they take pleasure.
translation_text.mn127:12.5: In the same way, it’s not that those deities think,
translation_text.mn127:12.6: ‘What we have is permanent, lasting, and eternal.’ Rather, wherever those deities cling, that’s where they take pleasure.”
translation_text.mn127:13.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha:
translation_text.mn127:13.3: I have a further question about this.
translation_text.mn127:13.4: Do all the radiant deities have limited radiance, or do some there have limitless radiance?”
translation_text.mn127:13.5: “In that respect, Reverend Kaccāna, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance.”
translation_text.mn127:14.1: “What is the cause, Honorable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance?”
translation_text.mn127:14.2: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I’ll ask you about this in return, and you can answer as you like.
translation_text.mn127:14.3: What do you think, Reverend Kaccāna?
translation_text.mn127:14.4: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading as expansive the extent of a single tree root, or two or three tree roots?”
translation_text.mn127:14.6: “When a mendicant meditates on two or three tree roots.”
translation_text.mn127:14.9: Which of these two kinds of mental development is more expansive: when a mendicant meditates focused on pervading as expansive the extent of two or three tree roots, or a single village district …
translation_text.mn127:14.27: “When a mendicant meditates on this land surrounded by ocean.”
translation_text.mn127:14.29: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have limited radiance, while some have limitless radiance.”
translation_text.mn127:15.2: I have a further question about this.
translation_text.mn127:15.3: Do all the radiant deities have corrupted radiance, or do some there have pure radiance?”
translation_text.mn127:15.4: “In that respect, Reverend Kaccāna, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”
translation_text.mn127:16.1: “What is the cause, Venerable Anuruddha, what is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance?”
translation_text.mn127:16.2: “Well then, Reverend Kaccāna, I shall give you a simile.
translation_text.mn127:16.3: For by means of a simile some sensible people understand the meaning of what is said.
translation_text.mn127:16.4: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with impure oil and impure wick.
translation_text.mn127:16.5: Because of the impurity of the oil and the wick it burns dimly, as it were.
translation_text.mn127:16.6: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates focused on pervading ‘corrupted radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:16.7: Their physical discomfort is not completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is not completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse are not completely eliminated.
translation_text.mn127:16.8: Because of this they practice absorption dimly, as it were.
translation_text.mn127:16.9: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of corrupted radiance.
translation_text.mn127:16.10: Suppose an oil lamp was burning with pure oil and pure wick.
translation_text.mn127:16.11: Because of the purity of the oil and the wick it doesn’t burn dimly, as it were.
translation_text.mn127:16.12: In the same way, take some mendicant who meditates focused on pervading ‘pure radiance’.
translation_text.mn127:16.13: Their physical discomfort is completely settled, their dullness and drowsiness is completely eradicated, and their restlessness and remorse is completely eliminated.
translation_text.mn127:16.14: Because of this they don’t practice absorption dimly, as it were.
translation_text.mn127:16.15: When their body breaks up, after death, they’re reborn in the company of the gods of pure radiance.
translation_text.mn127:16.16: “This is the cause, Reverend Kaccāna, this is the reason why, when those deities have been reborn in a single order of gods, some deities there have corrupted radiance, while some have pure radiance.”
translation_text.mn127:17.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Venerable Anuruddha,
translation_text.mn127:17.4: ‘So I have heard’ or ‘It ought to be like this.’
translation_text.mn127:17.5: Rather, you say: ‘These deities are like this, those deities are like that.’
translation_text.mn127:17.7: ‘Clearly, Venerable Anuruddha has previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.’”
translation_text.mn127:17.8: “Your words are clearly invasive and intrusive, Reverend Kaccāna.
translation_text.mn127:17.10: For a long time I have previously lived together with those deities, conversed, and engaged in discussion.”
translation_text.mn127:18.1: When he had spoken, Venerable Sabhiya Kaccāna said to Pañcakaṅga the chamberlain,
translation_text.mn127:18.3: to have given up your state of uncertainty, and to have got the chance to listen to this exposition of the teaching.”

variant_text.mn127:4.2: appamāṇaṁ, gahapati, cetovimuttiṁ bhāvehī’ti → appamāṇā gahapati cetovimutti bhāvetabbāti (mr)
variant_text.mn127:18.3: mayañcimaṁ → yampimaṁ (sya-all, km, pts1ed) | pahāsi → pajahasi (mr)

reference_text.mn127:13.1: csp1ed11.188, csp2ed11.188, dr13.264, ms11M_623, msdiv233, nya13, pts-vp-pli3.149
